_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Facility Policy  

Farm Service Company, has an active Training program with all employees. The facility has coordinated with Local Emergency Personnel in event of accidental release and comply with CFR 1910.38. 
If an accidental  release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, Fremont County LEPC, and or any other authorities, to mitigate and minimize the impacts of the release to the people and the envirnoment.

Facility Information
                                                                                                                 
Farm Service Company, 109 Depot Street, Randolph, IA has 2 - 12,000 gallon tanks which are used for the storage of Anhydrous Ammonia (NH3).  The primary activity of our facility is the storage of fertilizer for sale to farmers.  The maximum quantitiy stored would be 299,250 pounds in storage tanks and nurse tanks.                                

Worse-Case Scenario and Alternate Release Scenario

The worse case scenario would be the release of the total contents of a storage tank released as a gas over a period of 10 minutes. The maximum quantitiy released would be 52,250 pounds, which represents the volume of the largest storage tank at 85% capacity as limited by design standards.  The distance to the end point is 1.2 miles.  Farm Service Company has excess flow valves, emergency shut-off valves and breakaway valves in place, required by th ANSI Standards and State Requirements.  These will help limit exposure in a release situation.                                                                                                                                                               

The alternate release scenario:  

The most likely potential incident, would be a release from a transfer hose failure.  Excess flow valves and remote manual shut-off valves are installed to stop the flow of ammonia.  The maximum quantity released would be 7200 pounds over a 2 minute period of t

ime.  The distance to the endpoint (point of dispersion to 200 ppm) is .6 miles.
 
Accidental Release Prevention Program

General release prevention is covered in Employee training and all employees are aware of companies emergency action plan.  The facility is in compliance with the provisions of "Safety requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, k-61.1", published by The American National Standard Institute, Inc. (ANSI) , and the standards of the U.S.   Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111,  "Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia".  The ANSI standard has been adopted by reference by Iowa Administrative Code Part 21 - Chapter 43 - Rule 43.6 (200), "standard for the storage and handling of Anhydrous Ammonia".   The OSHA standard is referenced in this RMP Registration Form, see section 8.3 (b).                                                                                                                                                    

Five Year Accident History

No accidental release has taken place in the last five years with offsite exposure.  The facility has ongoing safety updates when the need arises.                                                                          

Emergency Action Plan

The company complies with CFR1910.38 Emergency Action plan and is included in County Emergency Response Plan.  The company provides state and local authorities with Sara Title III and Community Right to Know and Emergency Planning with the required information.  Farm Service Company has a Saftey Program in place.  Updates are added to the training agenda and are in implemented company wide.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

None.
